Yeah they're starting to jail those Genocidal Folks in Germany now too. Of course like most "we want revenge" or "oh golly we're sorry" prosecutions they've waited until they won't have to put a significant number of the population in prison. When we get around to accountability, afterall, there is usually plenty to go around, and not just on the losing side. Let's see, Guatemala . . . cold war years, see what it tells me when enough people die to charge "genocide" and only one target is selected for trial, is that the trial is a sham. When the #$%$'s who orchestrated The Final Solution (the only real Genocide since the Turks and Armenians over half a century earlier) there were PLENTY of them to prosecute because implementing such an "action" is manpower intensive. While its possible Montt gave the orders though, where are those that carried them out? Are they going to prosecute EVERYONE who was with the Army or Police at the time? (Afterall in such a scenario all members of a unit are culpable) or isn't that political acceptable. For if Germany had tried to send everyone associated with the Death Camps to a camp themselves at the close of the war, we'd have had the few surviving prisoners, and the US Army, guarding most of the German population, and a good portion of the Russian and "Polish" liberating Armies. Yes, culpability is VERY easy to assign when you wait a half a century to do it.

Message.Title: Capitalist Spring
Message.Msg: The Economist announces it in a headline: "Wall Street is back". The New York Stock Exchange has witnessed almost uninterrupted growth since the beginning of the year. On May 7, the Dow Jones Index crossed the symbolic line of 15,000 points. If the robust American markets sound the return of growth in the United States, activity seems to be stirring in Europe as well, as shown by March's positive figures in industrial production in Germany and the United Kingdom. In terms of debt, the situation appears to be stabilising with Portugal's return to the market, the possible return of Greece by the end of 2014, and borrowing rates at a three-year low in Spain.

Jump to: navigation, search The presidency of Ronald Reagan in the United States was marked by multiple scandals, resulting in the investigation, indictment, or conviction of over 138 administration officials, the largest number for any US president.[1]
